questions.question: When you look back at past relationships or dating experiences, which red flags do you now recognize that you initially overlooked?
options: Love bombing or moving too fast emotionally
Isolating me from friends or family
Avoiding serious conversations about the future
I haven't experienced significant red flags
questions.purpose: Assess learning from past experiences and ability to identify concerning patterns

questions.question: If someone you're dating exhibits one of your identified dealbreakers early on, what would you most likely do?
options: Address it directly in conversation immediately
Give them one chance to explain or change

Reflect on whether it's truly a dealbreaker for me
questions.purpose: Evaluate assertiveness and follow-through on stated boundaries

questions.question: How important is it to you that a potential partner respects your non-negotiable boundaries from the very beginning?

questions.question: Which of these behaviors would you consider an immediate red flag on a first or second date?
options: Making inappropriate jokes about sensitive topics
None of these would be immediate dealbreakers
questions.purpose: Identify early warning sign recognition and safety awareness

questions.question: Have you ever stayed in a relationship despite recognizing red flags? If so, what was your primary reason?
options: I believed they would change over time
I didn't want to be alone
I thought I could help or fix them
The good moments outweighed the bad
I doubted my own judgment or instincts
Fear of confrontation or their reaction
questions.purpose: Understand vulnerability to ignoring warning signs and underlying motivations

questions.question: What would help you feel most confident in identifying and acting on red flags in future relationships?
options: Better understanding of what constitutes healthy vs unhealthy behavior
Stronger sense of self-worth and deserving better
Support from friends or family to validate my concerns
Learning to trust my instincts more
Clear personal values and dealbreakers established beforehand
Past experience has already taught me this
I already feel confident in this area
questions.purpose: Identify areas for growth and support needs in developing safety awareness

questions.question: Do you notice any recurring patterns in the types of people you're attracted to or who are attracted to you?
options: Yes, and I recognize some patterns are unhealthy
Yes, and the patterns have generally been positive
Yes, but I'm unsure if the patterns are helpful or harmful
Somewhat, but patterns aren't very clear
No, each person has been quite different
I haven't dated enough to identify patterns
questions.purpose: Assess self-awareness of relationship patterns and attraction dynamics

questions.question: When you think about your past relationships or dating experiences, which pattern (if any) do you recognize?
options: I'm attracted to emotionally unavailable people
I tend to take on a caretaker or fixer role
I pursue people who seem uninterested or distant
I lose interest once someone shows genuine interest
I repeat similar conflicts or issues across relationships
I attract people with similar problematic traits
I move too quickly into serious commitment
I don't recognize any negative patterns
questions.purpose: Identify specific attachment or behavioral patterns that may indicate areas for growth

questions.question: How often do you find yourself making excuses for a partner's behavior or explaining away concerns that others point out?

Others rarely express concerns about my partners
I'm not sure or can't recall
questions.purpose: Evaluate tendency to rationalize red flags and minimize valid concerns

questions.question: Have you noticed whether your relationships tend to follow a similar trajectory or timeline?
options: Yes, they often end around the same time for similar reasons
Yes, they follow a similar pattern of intensity then decline
Somewhat, there are similarities but also differences
No, each relationship has been unique in how it developed
I haven't had enough relationships to identify a pattern
I haven't thought about this before
questions.purpose: Assess awareness of cyclical relationship patterns and potential underlying issues

questions.question: When a relationship ends, do you typically find that the reasons for ending are similar to previous relationships?
options: Yes, very similar issues or incompatibilities

I'm usually the one ending relationships for different reasons each time
Partners usually end things, and reasons vary
I haven't had enough relationships to compare
I haven't reflected on this pattern

How do you prefer to communicate when something is bothering you in a relationship?

options.text: Think it through first, then bring it up when calm
Drop hints and hope they notice
Wait to see if it resolves itself

questions.text: What's your ideal frequency for deep, meaningful conversations with your partner?

options.text: Daily - I need constant emotional connection
A few times a week is perfect
As needed - I prefer lighter daily interactions

questions.text: How do you typically share good news with your partner?

options.text: Call or text them immediately, they're the first to know
Tell them in person when I see them next
Share it casually when it comes up naturally
Sometimes forget to mention it until much later

questions.text: When discussing important topics, what communication approach works best for you?

options.text: I like to write out my thoughts first, then discuss
Phone or video calls work just as well
Text conversations help me process and respond thoughtfully

questions.text: How do you prefer your partner to ask about your day?

options.text: Ask me specific questions to draw out details
Give me space to share what I want when ready
Start with a general 'how was your day?' and let it flow
Share their day first, then I'll naturally share mine

questions.text: What's your texting style with a romantic partner throughout the day?

options.text: Frequent check-ins and updates throughout the day
A few messages to stay connected
Minimal texting - I prefer to connect in person
Depends on my schedule and mood that day

questions.text: How do you handle it when your partner misunderstands what you said?

options.text: Feel frustrated but try to explain differently
Ask what they heard to understand the disconnect
Let it go if it's not too important

questions.text: What's your approach to discussing future plans with your partner?

options.text: I like detailed discussions and clear timelines
Big picture conversations with some flexibility
Prefer to take things as they come

questions.text: How direct do you prefer communication to be in a relationship?

options.text: Extremely direct - say exactly what you mean
Honest but tactful with careful word choice
Gentle and indirect to avoid hurt feelings
It depends on the sensitivity of the topic

questions.text: When you need space to process something, how do you communicate that to your partner?

options.text: Tell them explicitly that I need time alone
Say I need space but explain why
Become quieter and hope they pick up on it
I don't usually need space from my partner

questions.text: What's your instinct when a disagreement starts with your partner?

options.text: Engage fully and work through it right away
Take a short break to cool down, then discuss
Avoid conflict and try to smooth things over
Withdraw until I've processed my feelings

questions.text: After an argument, what helps you feel like things are resolved?

options.text: A clear verbal agreement and understanding
Time passing and returning to normal
Seeing changed behavior that addresses the issue

questions.text: How do you typically apologize when you're in the wrong?

options.text: Direct apology with acknowledgment of what I did
Show through actions rather than words
I struggle to apologize even when I know I should

questions.text: What's your approach when your partner is angry but you don't think you did anything wrong?

options.text: Listen to understand their perspective, even if I disagree
Defend my position and explain my reasoning
Apologize to keep the peace, even if I don't feel at fault
Give them space to cool off before discussing

questions.text: How long can you sit with unresolved tension in a relationship?

options.text: Minutes - I need to resolve things immediately
A few hours to cool down is okay
A day or two if we both need space
I can let things go and move on without discussing

questions.text: What's most important to you during a disagreement?

options.text: Finding a solution to the problem
Getting to the root cause of the issue

questions.text: How do you handle it when the same issue keeps coming up in your relationship?

options.text: Suggest trying a completely different approach
Express frustration that it's not resolved yet
Consider if it's a compatibility issue
Accept it as something we'll always navigate

questions.text: During a heated discussion, what's your biggest challenge?

options.text: Staying calm and not raising my voice
Listening instead of planning my response

questions.text: What role does compromise play in your conflict resolution style?

options.text: I'm always willing to meet in the middle
I compromise on small things but stand firm on big issues
I tend to give in to avoid prolonged conflict
I prefer finding creative solutions where both get what they need

questions.text: How do you feel about involving others (friends, family, therapist) when you're having relationship conflicts?

options.text: I think it's helpful to get outside perspective
Only for serious issues or professional help
I prefer to keep relationship issues private
I vent to friends but don't seek their advice

questions.text: How do you most naturally show someone you care about them?

options.text: Doing things to make their life easier

questions.text: What makes you feel most loved by a partner?

options.text: When they prioritize time with me
Thoughtful gifts that show they know me

questions.text: What's your ideal level of physical affection in a relationship?

Moderate - meaningful moments but not constant

options.text: Essential - I need to hear it regularly
Not very - I know by how they treat me

options.text: Something that shows they listen and know me well

options.text: Appreciative - it's nice but not my main love language
Grateful but I'd prefer other gestures

questions.text: What kind of compliments mean the most to you?

options.text: About my character and who I am as a person
About my efforts and what I do
Specific observations that show they pay attention

questions.text: How do you prefer to celebrate special occasions with your partner?

options.text: Quality time together doing something special

questions.text: When you're having a bad day, what do you most want from your partner?

options.text: Help with tasks to take things off my plate

I prefer to keep affection private

Going out and experiencing something new

options.text: Very little - I prefer being with my partner

questions.text: How do you feel about doing separate activities while in the same room?

questions.text: What's your ideal frequency for date nights?

options.text: Very - I want to share my passions with them
Somewhat - at least one or two shared interests

I prefer we have mostly different hobbies

questions.text: When spending time together, what matters most to you?

options.text: Simply being in each other's presence
Accomplishing something or being productive together

questions.text: How do you feel about phones and screens during couple time?

options.text: Quick checks are fine but no scrolling
Okay unless we're deep in conversation

questions.text: What's your stance on spending time with your partner's friends or family?

options.text: Love it - they're part of my partner's life
It's fine but I'd rather have one-on-one time
Prefer to keep our time together just us two

questions.text: How do you prefer to wind down together at the end of the day?

options.text: Parallel activities - near each other but doing our own thing

questions.text: What's your ideal balance of routine versus spontaneity in couple time?

options.text: Mostly routine with occasional spontaneous moments
Good mix of both - planned and spontaneous

questions.text: How do you view the concept of maintaining separate friend groups in a relationship?

options.text: Essential - we each need our own friends
Healthy to have some separate and some shared

questions.text: How comfortable are you making major life decisions independently while in a relationship?

options.text: Depends on if it affects them
I'd discuss most major decisions with them first
We should make all major decisions together

questions.text: What's your ideal living situation in a committed relationship?

options.text: Living together is essential for me
Living together but each having our own space/room
Living very close but separate places
Comfortable with significant distance between homes

questions.text: How do you feel about traveling without your partner?

options.text: Love it - solo travel or trips with friends are important to me
Occasionally for work or special trips
Rarely - I prefer we experience things together

questions.text: How merged should finances be in a serious relationship?

options.text: Completely shared - what's mine is ours
